awd_titl_txt: CAREER: SusChEM: Copper-Catalyzed Aerobic Dehydrogenative C-C Bond Formation through sp3 C-H Bond Functionalization
awd_abstract_narration:
This project, funded by the NSF Chemical Synthesis Program, supports the research of Professor Haibo Ge of the Department of Chemistry and Chemical Biology at Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis (IUPUI). Professor Ge's research involves environmentally-friendly and atom-efficient methods for preparing important organic molecules.  The successful development of this research has an impact on the fields of synthetic organic, medicinal, and agricultural chemistries.  The training of undergraduate and graduate students for entry into the workforce is also a key part of this project.  A new course and a new undergraduate laboratory experiment are being developed.  These courses focus on the integration of transition-metal-catalyzed and heterocyclic chemistry in the curriculum.  The summer undergraduate research program improves retention and engagement among chemistry and biochemistry students at IUPUI, and facilitates their entry into the job market or graduate/professional school.

Professor Ge is developing methods for the conversion of sp3-hybridized carbon-hydrogen bonds into carbon-carbon bonds using copper-catalyzed reactions conducted under an atmosphere of oxygen. These direct, catalytic dehydrogenative carbon-carbon bond-forming reactions achieve the selective oxidation of sp3 carbons adjacent to a heteroatom (nitrogen or oxygen) or an imino group (carbon-nitrogen double bond) in a variety of starting substrates.  The processes are extended to achieve efficient syntheses of a variety of heterocyclic compounds.  The diastereoselective and enantioselective (using chiral catalysts) variants of these processes are also being studied.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The efficient conversion of common petroleum chemicals into functionally versatile products is one of the most significant and challenging demands in organic chemistry. The site-selective, single-step, introduction of functional groups into petroleum feedstock via C-H bond functionalization promises the production of valuable building blocks for the agrochemical, pharmaceutical, and material industries. However, the inertness of the relatively non-polar C-H bonds and their high dissociation energies render them poor reaction components. Moreover, desired site-selectivity is often an issue in reactions involving multiple analogous C-H bonds, which is often the case with hydrocarbon-based materials like petroleum feedstock.

The use of transition metals to catalyze C-H bond functionalization reactions involves weakening proximal C-H bonds selectively. Therefore, a specific C-H bond in the vicinity of the metal binding could be cleaved and functionalized on demand. Using this strategy, we have discovered dehydrogenative coupling reactions of hydrazones in a highly site- and diastereoselective manner, resulting in efficient access to dihydropyrazoles, important structural units in pharmaceutics. Additionally, we have developed direct carbonylation of aromatic sp2 and sp3 C-H bonds of amides via nickel/copper synergistic catalysis in a highly site-selective process. Notably, this work represented the first example of transition metal-catalyzed site-selective nucleophilic addition involving unactivated Csp3-H bonds. This carbonylation protocol is significant as it allows ready access to succinimides, common structural motifs in organic synthesis. Most notably, we have employed a ?transient directing group? strategy utilizing relatively inexpensive and readily available materials to construct carbon-carbon and carbon-heteroatom bonds in highly site-selective fashion. Specifically, we have designed a co-catalytic system using commercially available palladium acetate as a metal catalyst in combination with glyoxylic acid as an organic catalyst, successfully achieving direct γ-arylation of primary alkylamines. Furthermore, we have demonstrated the substantial utility of this method by preparing the immunomodulating drug Fingolimod in the most efficient way to date. Encouraged by these results, we have expanded our studies to include aliphatic and aromatic aldehydes alike using the same strategy, affording a series of novel organic fluorescence materials bearing unique mechanochromic properties. Next, we have developed a remote site-selective arylation reaction of aliphatic aldehydes. This novel arylation reaction is highlighted by the domination of γ-functionalization, an originally unlikely outcome of such reactions evidenced by the completely different results from previously reported processes. Notably, this work represented the first such example of transition metal-catalyzed remote C-H bond functionalization reactions of simple organic molecules via 6-membered ring intermediacy. These discoveries not only greatly broaden the substrate scopes and product diversities, but also inspire further studies in the field of transition metal catalysis.

To date, this project has produced sixteen peer-reviewed publications. In addition, it provided research opportunities to a number of undergraduate and graduate students, research and visiting scholars, and post-doctoral researchers from Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis and Texas Tech University. The technical and intellectual knowledge and skills obtained during this research project have benefited these individuals in their admissions to graduate and professional schools, as well as securing jobs in academia and industry.

 


Last Modified: 02/05/2021
Modified by: Haibo Ge
